header.title: The Book of Tahuti (Thoth): Fragments thereof

central_thesis: Charles Pace's 'Book of Tahuti' presents a unique, comprehensive system of Hermetic and Egyptian magic, reinterpreting traditional deities and integrating them with detailed Tarot attributions, elemental forces, and a Luciferian philosophy focused on personal transformation and 'isolate becoming' as practiced within 'The Order of Phosphorus'.

structure_content.chapter_title: Introduction to Charles Pace and his Magical Works
structure_content.summary: This section provides biographical context for Charles Pace (Hamar'at), detailing his background as a Priest of Set and Anubis, a 'Black Adept' of Hermetic Magick, and later a High Priest of a Gardnerian Wiccan Coven. It outlines his major unpublished manuscripts, 'The Book of Tahuti' (focusing on Egyptian gods/goddesses and Tarot) and 'Necrominion, the Book of Shades' (exploring the Sethanic Cult of Masks and 'Ankh Ka' sex magick). Pace's connections to prominent occult figures like Aleister Crowley, Austin Osman Spare, Gerald Gardner, and Anton LaVey are highlighted, positioning his work within a broader 20th-century esoteric landscape.

structure_content.chapter_title: Philosophical Foundation: Luciferianism and The Order of Phosphorus
structure_content.summary: Pace's core philosophy is explicitly stated as 'Luciferian,' emphasizing 'Magick, transformation and an isolate approach to becoming.' This is the underlying principle of his work and practices within 'The Order of Phosphorus (TOPH).' The Sethanic Cult of Masks, detailed in 'Necrominion,' is a key component, suggesting a path of self-initiation through adversarial or shadow work, distinct from conventional magical paradigms.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Triple Hermetic Circle of Hamar'at
structure_content.summary: This is a central practical and symbolic tool developed by Pace for TOPH. It's depicted as a complex mandala-like diagram integrating directional forces (North, East, South, West) with a central hexagram and surrounding symbolic names ('ANKH-KA-DJED-ANKH', 'RA-DJED'). A corresponding table details 24 Egyptian deities (e.g., Aset, Sekhmet, Anpa/Anubis), their associated qualities (LOVE, HATE, LIFE, DEATH, WAR, PEACE, TRUTH, WISDOM, IGNORANCE, CREATION), elemental correspondences (WATER, EARTH, FIRE, AIR), and specific angular degrees, forming a precise system for attunement and ritual work.

structure_content.chapter_title: Reinterpretation of Egyptian Deities and Tarot Correspondences
structure_content.summary: Pace presents a radical reinterpretation of key Egyptian deities and their relation to the Tarot. He asserts that Tahuti (Thoth) was not Hermes, and that Anubis (Anpu) – 'Lord of the Jackals, Opener of the Ways, Keeper of the Balance, The Magician' – was responsible for writing the Books. Anubis is further identified as a mortal bastard son of Seth-an and Aset (Isis). This system meticulously attributes Egyptian numbers, Tarot numbers, and guardian deities to specific Major and Minor Arcana cards, emphasizing elemental (Fire, Air, Water, Earth) and directional associations, as seen in examples like Strength (Imset/Water), Temperance (Duamutef/Fire), Death (Imset/Water), The Chariot (Hapy/Earth), and The Hanged Man (Duamutef/Fire).

structure_content.chapter_title: Elemental Systems: The Four True Triangles and Enneads
structure_content.summary: The work details 'The Four True Triangles' symbolizing Earth, Air, Fire, and Water, with Earth associated with the 'Triad of Light' and Water with the 'Triad of Darkness.' These elemental frameworks underpin the 'Enneads' (sets of nine or twelve) within each Tarot suit. For instance, the 'Ennead of Fire (Swords)' provides a comprehensive list of Egyptian deities and Tarot figures (e.g., Thoth as The Hanged Man, Osiris as The Hierophant). Similar 'Enneads' are presented for Wands (Air) and Cups (Water), each with specific guardians (e.g., Qebehsenuf for Air, Imset for Water), numbers, and represented concepts.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Great Ennead of Twelve and Practical Application of Tarot
structure_content.summary: A circular diagram illustrates 'The Great Ennead of Twelve (Opposing factions),' mapping twelve deities (e.g., Ahun-Ra, Horus, Sekhmet, Thoth) in a wheel, suggesting a system of balanced or complementary forces. The text elaborates on the 'Ennead of Fire's' structure, detailing which Major and Minor Arcana cards 'right-fully belong' to specific quarters (e.g., Thoth (12) in the Triad of Swords, Bast (8) in the Ennead of Water, Nephthys (10) in the Ennead of Air), providing a complex framework for interpreting and utilizing the Tarot within Pace's unique magical context.

key_concepts.definition: Charles Pace's magical name, indicating his role as a practitioner and developer of esoteric systems.
Charles Pace's unpublished manuscript, serving as the foundational text for his unique system of Hermetic and Egyptian magic, particularly concerning Tarot attributions and deity reinterpretations.
Pace's other unpublished manuscript, which elaborates on the teachings of the Sethanic Cult of Masks, High Sex Magick rituals like 'Ankh Ka', and its Luciferian philosophical underpinnings.

A core magical and philosophical framework within Pace's system, linked to Luciferian principles, focused on 'transformation and an isolate approach to becoming' through specific teachings and practices.
A magical organization where Charles Pace's system, including the Triple Hermetic Circle, was developed and practiced, embodying his Luciferian philosophy.

A significant ritual working and symbolic construct developed by Pace, characterized by a complex diagrammatic representation of deities, qualities, elements, and angular degrees, intended for Magick, transformation, and isolate becoming.

Pace's revisionist understanding where Tahuti (Thoth) is distinct from Hermes, and Anpu (Anubis) is identified as the true author of the 'Books,' 'Lord of the Jackals,' 'Opener of the Ways,' 'Keeper of the Balance,' and 'The Magician,' and presented as the mortal, bastard son of Seth-an and Aset (Isis).
A system of twelve deities arranged in a circular diagram, illustrating a framework of balanced or opposing archetypal forces and their interrelationships within Pace's magical cosmology.

Symbolic representations of the four classical elements (Earth, Air, Fire, Water), with Earth correlating to the 'Triad of Light' and Water to the 'Triad of Darkness,' forming an elemental foundation for the system.

practical_system.description: Pace's system is a meticulously structured operative magical framework designed for personal transformation and 'isolate becoming,' anchored in Egyptian deity work, elemental forces, and a re-contextualized Tarot. It combines detailed correspondences (deity, quality, element, degree) with specific ritual constructs. The system aims to align the practitioner with a Luciferian current of self-sovereignty and magical self-realization through specific invocations, meditations, and divinatory practices using the elaborated Tarot and I Ching.
tools: Reinterpreted Tarot Deck (with specific Egyptian deity, elemental, and numerical attributions)
I Ching (as a primary method of divination)
Symbolic Diagrams (e.g., The Triple Hermetic Circle, The Great Ennead of Twelve, Four True Triangles, Tarot Quarter Diagrams) for visualization and ritual mapping
rituals: Triple Hermetic Circle of Hamar'at (a foundational ritual working for personal transformation and alignment)
Ankh Ka (a described High Sex Magick ritual mentioned in Necrominion)
Serpent Castings using Hexagrams (a divination method mentioned in conjunction with I Ching)

relevant_quotes.text: The essence is Magick, transformation and an isolate approach to becoming. No matter what name is used, what symbolism is used, the focus is indeed Luciferian.
Thus, as my life, nears its end, I give the secret of my circle — to those amongst you — who would dare to use it — Memento — Hori-

Know you that Tahuti (Thoth) was not Hermes – Anubis (Messenger) and Death was Hermes – The GREEKS called him Hermanubis – but in Egypt he was known as ANPU (Lord of the JACKALS. (OPENER OF THE WAYS) the Keeper of the Balance – The Magician. The Books were written by Anubis (Anpu) whilst he was mortal, and was the Bastard – of Seth-an, and Aset (Isis) – which gives the clue to the 2nd

This fragment manuscript is for TOPH members only, and must not be shared outside of our circle. The Witches Pyramid is very much alive here, do not break this oath. Keep this for your own knowledge and let the Cursing and Creating be!

critical_analysis.relevance: Charles Pace's work is highly relevant to understanding the syncretic and evolving landscape of 20th-century Western Esotericism. It provides a rare glimpse into a unique system that blends Hermeticism, Egyptian magic, and explicitly Luciferian philosophy with a detailed, operative Tarot system. His radical reinterpretation of Thoth/Anubis challenges conventional occult attributions and demonstrates the ongoing creative adaptation within magical traditions. The explicit 'Luciferian' focus offers valuable insight into non-Thelemic, self-deification paths during this period, differentiating it from more mainstream Hermetic or Wiccan currents.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience includes advanced practitioners and scholars of Western Esotericism, particularly those specializing in Hermetic Qabalah, Egyptian magic, and Luciferian currents. Individuals interested in alternative Tarot systems, esoteric history, and the practices of groups like 'The Order of Phosphorus' would find this work invaluable. Its technical detail also appeals to experienced magicians seeking practical frameworks for personal transformation and deity interaction.
